name: Language Barrier Caller - Blood Pressure Monitor
description: Non-native English speaker reporting blood pressure monitor malfunction. Simple vocabulary, some confusion, requires patient clarification.

transcript.speaker: agent
transcript.text: HealthMonitor customer service, this is Kevin. How can I help you?

transcript.speaker: caller
transcript.text: Hello? Yes, hello. I have problem with machine. Blood pressure machine.

transcript.speaker: agent
transcript.text: You're having a problem with a blood pressure monitor? Can you tell me what's happening?

transcript.speaker: caller
transcript.text: Yes, the machine, it say my blood pressure very low. Every time, it say low. 90, 85, like this. But I feel... how you say... dizzy? No good.

transcript.speaker: agent
transcript.text: The machine is showing low blood pressure readings?

transcript.speaker: caller
transcript.text: Yes, yes. But doctor say no! Doctor say my blood pressure high. Very high. 180, 170. He give medicine. But machine at home say low. I am confuse.

transcript.speaker: agent
transcript.text: Oh, so the machine shows low readings but your doctor says your blood pressure is actually high?

transcript.speaker: caller
transcript.text: Yes! Exactly. I stop taking medicine because machine say low. Then I get very sick. Go hospital. Doctor very angry.

transcript.speaker: agent
transcript.text: I understand. You stopped your medication based on the home monitor and then had to go to the hospital?

transcript.speaker: caller
transcript.text: Yes. I have... my daughter help me say... stroke? Small stroke. Because blood pressure too high. But I think low because of machine!

transcript.speaker: agent
transcript.text: I'm so sorry to hear that. Can you tell me which blood pressure monitor you have?

transcript.speaker: caller
transcript.text: Uhh... I have paper. QuickCheck... Pro something. QuickCheck Pro 200? I buy from pharmacy, six month ago maybe.

transcript.speaker: agent
transcript.text: QuickCheck Pro 200, okay. Is there a number on the machine? A serial number?

transcript.speaker: caller
transcript.text: Number? Let me look... is small. QCP-22... no wait... QCP2-2023-34521. Yes, this one.

transcript.speaker: agent
transcript.text: Thank you. Do you still have the machine?

transcript.speaker: caller
transcript.text: Yes, I keep. My daughter say keep for you. For company. She very smart, my daughter.

transcript.speaker: agent
transcript.text: That's good. What date did this happen, when you had to go to the hospital?

transcript.speaker: caller
transcript.text: Last week. Thursday I think. March... 14? Yes, Thursday March 14.

transcript.speaker: agent
transcript.text: And can I get your name and phone number for follow-up?

transcript.speaker: caller
transcript.text: My name Tran Nguyen. Phone 555-234-8823. But better call daughter. She speak better English. Christina, 555-234-5567.

transcript.speaker: agent
transcript.text: Thank you, Mr. Nguyen. We will investigate this and contact you soon. Do you have a new blood pressure monitor now?

transcript.speaker: caller
transcript.text: Yes, hospital give me different one. This one work good. Same as doctor machine.

transcript.speaker: agent
transcript.text: Good. Please continue using that one and taking your medication as your doctor prescribed.

transcript.speaker: caller
transcript.text: Yes, yes. I learn lesson. Thank you, thank you.

event_info.event_description: Blood pressure monitor consistently displayed falsely low readings (90, 85 systolic) when patient's actual blood pressure was severely elevated (170-180 systolic per physician). Patient discontinued hypertension medication based on false readings. Patient subsequently suffered TIA/minor stroke due to uncontrolled hypertension and was hospitalized.
event_info.device_outcome: Device retained by patient for evaluation

expected_complaint.narrative: Patient reports QuickCheck Pro 200 blood pressure monitor (S/N QCP2-2023-34521) giving consistently false low readings (85-90 systolic) when actual blood pressure was high (170-180 per physician). Patient discontinued hypertension medication based on inaccurate device readings. Patient suffered TIA/mini-stroke on March 14 and was hospitalized. Device purchased approximately 6 months ago, retained for evaluation.

ground_truth.coding_rationale: A0803 (Inaccurate Result) or A0201 (Device Displays Inaccurate Data) for falsely low BP readings. C0701 (Cerebrovascular Accident/Stroke) for TIA. MDR required due to serious injury (stroke) causally linked to device malfunction.

extraction_challenges: Causal chain must be pieced together
Caller confuses sequence of events initially
notes: Important case demonstrating device malfunction leading directly to patient harm. Language barrier adds extraction difficulty but caller provides essential information with agent assistance. Daughter available for follow-up with better English.
